  • KristÃ½na Helm

    Vice President AOBP | University Lecturer | Keynote Speaker

    4mo

    âœ… Speaking at a football stadium on why I donÂ´t believe in dual-use innovation. Today, I had the privilege of speaking at the SAPIE Forum in Bratislava, hosted in a truly unique venue â€“ the VIP rooms of the football stadium transformed into a conference hall! I delivered a keynote on â€œInnovation for Security and Growth: Europeâ€™s Dual-Useâ€ and joined a panel discussion with Oleksandr Bulatnikov and Marek Plavcan on â€œFrom Lab to Battlefield to Marketplace: Scaling Dual-Use Technologiesâ€, expertly moderated by Marian Majer. I opened my talk by explaining why I donâ€™t really believe in the concept of dual-use innovation. Many of the greatest technologies â€“ such as the internet or GPS â€“ originated in defence research before achieving transformative civilian applications. Others, like AI or autonomy, were driven by civilian curiosity and business needs, only later reshaping defence strategies. Crucially, these technologies were not born â€œdual-useâ€: their inventors focused on mastering one field before the innovations naturally crossed into another. Dual-use innovation is like multitasking: it doesnâ€™t work. You cannot fully unlock a technologyâ€™s potential if you try to design it simultaneously for two completely different markets, with distinct customers, purposes, and business models. In defence, there is essentially one customer â€“ the government â€“ and one type of end-user â€“ the armed forces. This creates limited scalability, strict regulation, and high risks, though also high rewards for the few who succeed. Civilian markets, in contrast, are much broader, less regulated, and more open to exploration. These are fundamentally different ecosystems that require different approaches â€“ especially for start-ups, where resources are scarce. Trying to chase both at once is like a skier attempting to win a race while pointing each leg in a different direction. This is why we see a huge gap between the many start-ups developing dual-use technologies and the very few who secure a first defence customer. So why is there so much enthusiasm for dual-use technologies? Because they sound like the perfect hybrid â€“ delivering both prosperity and security, in line with European values. But in reality, this narrative often masks the fact that Europe has chronically underfunded defence R&D. Dual-use is presented as a compromise: a way to care for our security while promising civilian growth. But is that truly the way best forward? We explored these questions in a very stimulating panel discussion. Thank you to SAPIE - Slovak Alliance for Innovation Economy and Jaroslav Bukovina for the invitation and excellent organisation! #Innovation #Defence #DualUse #Technology #Security #Europe #ResearchAndDevelopment #Startups #Policy #SAPIE #DefenceIndustry

  • Kalea Texeira
    3mo
    • Report this post

    ğ‡ğğ¥ğ¬ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğšğ§ğ ğğ®ğšğ§ğ­ğ®ğ¦ ğ’ğ²ğ¬ğ­ğğ¦ğ¬ ğ€ğ«ğ ğ’ğ¡ğ¨ğ©ğ©ğ¢ğ§ğ  â€” ğğ¨ğ­ ğ–ğšğ¢ğ­ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ­ğ¨ ğğ ğ’ğ¡ğ¨ğ©ğ©ğğ "We thought we had time to build everything in-house â€” then Helsing bought two companies in six months." Europe's best-funded defence tech startups have shifted strategy. Helsing acquired Blue Ocean and Grob Aircraft this year. Quantum Systems absorbed three companies. Stark and Tekever are following similar playbooks: buy capabilities, integrate fast, secure contracts. The acquisition wave isn't speculative. It's a strategic acceleration in response to budget signals and procurement timelines that governments are now publishing. The acquisitions aren't just about speed; they're about de-risking delivery. Government buyers want certified production and proven compliance systems, not blueprints. What's driving the M&A surge Germany is committed to allocating 3.5% of its GDP to defence by 2029. The UK pledged hundreds of millions for military tech and designated AI an immediate priority. Those aren't aspirational statements â€” they're contract forecasts. VC funding for European defense technology topped roughly â‚¬3.5 billion this yearâ€”nearly double the pace of last year. That capital carries growth expectations, and building autonomous fighter jets or underwater surveillance systems from scratch takes years. Acquiring proven manufacturing capacity, deep tech talent, and gap-filling technologies cuts the time-to-contract by half or more. What the new primes are buying Hardware companies with operational production lines Talent pools holding government clearances or regulatory expertise Technologies that close capability gaps without multi-year integration cycles Strategic implications Consolidation is arriving years ahead of forecasts. VCs expect major M&A activity in three to five years, particularly in the crowded drone segment, where one investor estimates that 90% of companies won't survive independently. But the best-funded startups aren't waiting to be acquired â€” they're becoming buyers. The shift redefines founder strategy: M&A readiness is now a growth requirement, not an exit consideration. Where do you sit in this new order? If you're building in defence or dual-use, assess your position: are you a buyer, a target, or neither yet? 1. Map your capability gaps against published contract requirements. 2. Identify acquisition candidates or strategic partnership opportunities in adjacent segments. 3. Build relationships with well-funded neo-primes operating in complementary categories. 4. Strengthen M&A readiness â€” financials, IP documentation, compliance infrastructure. 5. Track which platforms are shopping in your technology domain. M&A has become part of the operating model, not the endgame. It's not about exits. It's about speed, certification, and survivability. The question isn't whether consolidation is coming. It's a matter of when and whether you'll be shopping or on the shelf.
